title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For Retail Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in retail facilities
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for retail facilities. This certification covers lighting, HVAC, refrigeration, plug loads, and long operating hours typical of retail operations.

questions.question: In non-food retail facilities, what percentage of total energy is typically consumed by lighting?
questions.explanation: Lighting typically consumes 35-50% of total energy in non-food retail facilities. This is the largest single end use, making lighting optimization the highest priority for retail facilities.

questions.question: A retail store has T12 fluorescent fixtures that operate 14 hours/day. The store is considering LED replacement. What is the typical payback period?
questions.scenario: A retail store has 200 T12 fluorescent fixtures (32W each) operating 14 hours/day, 365 days/year. LED replacement fixtures (15W each) cost $50 per fixture installed. Electricity costs $0.12/kWh.
questions.explanation: Original: 200 √ó 32W = 6,400W = 6.4 kW √ó 14 hrs √ó 365 days = 32,704 kWh/year √ó $0.12 = $3,924/year. New: 200 √ó 15W = 3,000W = 3 kW √ó 14 hrs √ó 365 days = 15,330 kWh/year √ó $0.12 = $1,840/year. Savings: $2,084/year. Cost: 200 √ó $50 = $10,000. Payback: $10,000 / $2,084 = ~4.8 years. With utility rebates (typically $20-40/fixture), payback can be 2-3 years.

questions.question: A grocery store has open refrigerated cases (no doors). What is the energy impact of adding doors?
questions.explanation: Adding doors to open refrigerated cases can reduce refrigeration energy by 15-35%. Open cases lose significant cold air to the store, requiring constant cooling. Doors reduce this loss while maintaining product visibility with glass doors.

questions.question: What is the typical energy savings potential for LED lighting retrofits in retail facilities?
questions.explanation: LED lighting retrofits in retail facilities typically yield 40-70% energy savings, especially when replacing T12/T8 fluorescents or halogen fixtures. Additional savings (10-40%) can be achieved with controls (scheduling, occupancy, dimming).

questions.question: A retail store operates 14 hours/day. What HVAC scheduling opportunity exists?
questions.scenario: A retail store operates 8 AM - 10 PM (14 hours/day). The HVAC system runs continuously, including during closed hours for 'pre-cooling' or 'pre-heating'.

options.text: No opportunity - HVAC must run continuously
Optimize start/stop times to minimize runtime while maintaining comfort
Turn HVAC off completely when closed

questions.explanation: Optimizing HVAC start/stop times (optimal start/stop) can reduce HVAC energy by 10-20% by minimizing runtime while maintaining comfort. This balances energy savings with customer comfort. Complete shutdown may cause comfort issues, but reducing operation during closed hours is typically feasible.

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in retail facilities?

options.text: Interior Lighting, Exterior Lighting, HVAC, Refrigeration (if food retail)
HVAC, Lighting, Building Envelope, Plug Loads
Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Plug Loads
Plug Loads, Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope

questions.explanation: For retail facilities, Interior Lighting is typically Very High priority (35-50% of energy). Exterior Lighting is High priority. HVAC is High priority. Refrigeration is Very High priority for food retail. Retailers often prioritize quick payback (2-4 years).
